newsitem.title: USA: WSCC concerns may delay further rise in Intertie.
newsitem.headline: WSCC concerns may delay further rise in Intertie.

text.p: The board of the Western Systems Coordinating Council (WSCC) will meet Thursday to resolve concerns some members have with a proposal to raise capacity on Pacific Intertie power lines for the spring, a WSCC spokeswoman said Monday.
A WSCC study group has proposed raising the Intertie limit to 7,700 megawatts (MW) from the current 6,250 MW through the end of June.
But some WSCC members, particularly Southwest utilities, are worried about potential overloading of the lines and power outages.
Use of the 7,900 MW Intertie system was cut by 65 percent after two widespread power outages hit the West last summer.
But, after careful study of the system and implementation of safety measures, the capacity was raised to 6,250 MW at the end of March.
Following the WSCC board review on Thursday, general members will have 10 days, or until May 8, to comment on the plan.
If comments still express valid concerns, the board could take another 10 days to review them, the WSCC spokeswoman noted.
